perturbation.original_text: All subscription  funds received by Capital  Resources (and if by check  shall be made  payable to the  Company)  or by other  NASD  registered broker-dealers soliciting subscriptions (if any) shall be transmitted (either by U.S.  Mail  or  similar  type  of  transmittal)  to the  Company  by noon of the following business day.
perturbation.changed_text: All subscription funds received by Capital Resources (and if by check shall be made payable to the Company) or by other NASD registered broker-dealers soliciting subscriptions (if any) shall be transmitted (either by U.S. Mail or similar type of transmittal) to the Company within five business days.
perturbation.explanation: This change extends the timeframe for transmitting subscription funds to five business days, contradicting SEC Rule 15c2-4, which requires prompt transmission or deposit of customer funds, generally interpreted as the next business day.

perturbation.original_text: The Company will make generally  available to its security holders  as soon as  practicable,  but not later than 90 days after the close of the period an earnings  statement (in form complying with the provisions of Rule 158 under the 1933 Act) covering a twelve-month  period beginning not later than the first day of the Company's  fiscal quarter next following the effective date (as defined in said Rule 158) of the Registration Statement.
perturbation.changed_text: The Company will make generally available to its security holders as soon as practicable, but no later than 150 days after the close of the period, an earnings statement (in form complying with the provisions of Rule 158 under the 1933 Act) covering a twelve-month period beginning not later than the first day of the Company's fiscal quarter next following the effective date (as defined in said Rule 158) of the Registration Statement.
perturbation.explanation: This modification extends the deadline for providing earnings statements to 150 days, conflicting with the SEC's requirement for timely financial reporting. While the exact requirement depends on the filing type, extending to 150 days is likely to violate reporting deadlines for many companies.

perturbation.original_text: During the period during which the Company's  common stock is  registered  under  the 1934 Act or for  three  years  from the date  hereof, whichever  period is greater,  the Company will furnish to its  stockholders  as soon as  practicable  after  the  end of  each  fiscal  year  an  annual  report (including a balance sheet and  statements of income,  stockholders'  equity and changes in  financial  position or cash flow  statement of the Company as at the end of and for such  year,  certified  by  independent  public  accountants  and prepared in accordance with Regulation S-X under the 1934 Act).
perturbation.changed_text: During the period during which the Company's common stock is registered under the 1934 Act or for three years from the date hereof, whichever period is greater, the Company will furnish to its stockholders an annual report within 270 days of each fiscal year, certified by internal accountants and prepared in accordance with the company's internal procedures.
perturbation.explanation: This change introduces multiple inconsistencies. First, it extends the reporting deadline to 270 days, contradicting standard SEC filing timelines for annual reports (Form 10-K). Second, it allows for certification by 'internal accountants' instead of 'independent public accountants,' violating audit requirements for publicly traded companies. Finally, it replaces 'Regulation S-X' with 'the company's internal procedures,' which contravenes generally accepted accounting principles (GAAP).
perturbation.contradicted_law: SEC reporting requirements (e.g., Form 10-K deadlines), audit requirements, and GAAP
